body:
```
/mnt/storage/storage/synced/oneplus5 <nil>
```
Why the assertion in the first place? what are we trying to accomplish in unrootedChecked ?

@larroy 

Why asserting/panicing is a good question - it makes life easy for me as I don't need to think about how to handle a case that should never happen. A panic is ideal for that, as one line of code guarantees that the issue will come to my attention if it ever arises. Obviously, it's not quite user-friendly. All of that is tangential to your actual case though.

What needs figuring out is where the evaluation of symlinks in your filesystem instance failed, i.e. why there is this conflict:

panic: bug: Notify backend is processing a change outside of the filesystem root: root==/home/piotr/storage/synced/oneplus5/, **rootSymEval==/home/piotr/storage/synced/oneplus5/**, path==/mnt/storage/storage/synced/oneplus5/.stfolder

fmt.Println(filepath.EvalSymlinks("/home/piotr/storage/synced/oneplus5/"))
**/mnt/storage/storage/synced/oneplus5** <nil>

I can't reproduce this issue, so a bit of back and forth will be necessary (maybe I am also just missing the obvious). Can you check what's the path for your folder in config.xml and then adjust the path at the bottom of the following gist and run it (it's basically the relevant syncthing code with lots of verbosity):
https://gist.github.com/imsodin/b8ec2ec226a0575f7619997b287e6e28
Because the mount point is in /mnt/storage but in my home folder there's a link from ~/storage to /mnt/storage

The point of `rootSymEval` is exactly to resolve this issue, i.e. it should be the evaluated symlink as returned by `filepath.EvalSymlinks` und thus the same. Please run the gist and report the results.

Same panic happening here, setup similar to larroy's:

/oldssd/jamieson/  $ ls -l /home/
lrwxrwxrwx  1 root     root       17 Feb  6 21:36 jamieson -> /oldssd/jamieson/

Basically ran out of space on one of my SSD's, so just symlinked from another one with free space available. Reproduce: just add a new user and then symlink the home directory from somewhere else.

Here's the result of that gist:

```
newBasicFilesystem start: /home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/
newBasicFilesystem windows root hack: /home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera
newBasicFilesystem tilde expansion: /home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera
newBasicFilesystem EvalSymlinks: /oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera
adjustRoot in: /home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera
adjustRoot result: /home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/
adjustRoot in: /oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera
adjustRoot result: /oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/
&{/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/ /oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/}
```
Sorry I haven't been able to rerun, hadn't had access to that desktop for a bit.
@jamiesonbecker What was the panic message in your case (I am interested in the paths)? Thanks for running the gist!

@imsodin sure:

```
Panic at 2018-08-06T15:47:05-05:00
panic: bug: Notify backend is processing a change outside of the filesystem root: 
  root==/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/, 
  rootSymEval==/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/, 
  path==/oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/.stfolder
```

issue.title: DEBUG: Investigate #5043

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body: Not to be merged, just to try to understand #5043

body:
The weird thing is, that the gist (which is the exact same code with some debug statements) produces the correct result for the evaluated path `&{/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/ /oldssd/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/}` but it's wrong in the panic `rootSymEval==/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/,`. I have no idea, the next thing I'd try is move the debug info into the Syncthing binary and test again. A version on top of master from the build servers is here  
https://build.syncthing.net/repository/download/Syncthing_BuildLinuxCross/24994:id/syncthing-linux-amd64-v0.14.50-rc.1%2B3-gf9798d8.tar.gz%21/syncthing-linux-amd64-v0.14.50-rc.1%2B3-gf9798d8/syncthing  
and a version on top of 0.14.49 compile by me is here  
https://polybox.ethz.ch/index.php/s/ImkcFgiqQHxkCHt

Please run either of those until you get the panic again and post the logs here.

(Also, I was also getting a panic regarding "panic: cannot start already running folder", but that stopped once I disabled Auto-Accept and created that folder manually, with the same id: see also #5063 )

(403 on build.syncthing URL)

Can you confirm SHA256 `d8a9982d4a196d86ec0fc648f3c19860c5095852e372db176ed5ec8c69e3d7e9` on your polybox link above?

If I pause the folder that I'm getting running folder error on (from the same device) instead of disabling Auto-Accept, then I get this nice little issue (this is still running stock v0.14.49 on Arch):

```
[SGBHH] 09:52:17 INFO: Auto-accepted abcdef1234 folder "Ph1" (abc123) at path ~/Ph1
[SGBHH] 09:52:17 INFO: Connection to XXX at [yyy]:58648-[zzz]:22000/tcp-client closed: <nil>
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
```

(I can email you the full uncensored panic if you like.)

Just a hunch: these two issues (#5063 and this one, #5043) might be related to each other, especially when symlinks are thrown into the mix.

Your build produces the same nil pointer reference:

```
Panic at 2018-08-07T10:24:04-05:00
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
    panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x1 addr=0x18 pc=0x91f1cc]

goroutine 577 [running]:
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model.(*Model).Closed(0xc420211320, 0x7f3481835e60, 0xc4224d3710, 0x0, 0x0)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model/model.go:1262 +0x50c
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol.(*rawConnection).close.func1()
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol/protocol.go:833 +0x206
sync.(*Once).Do(0xc420730148, 0xc420efb120)
    /media/ext4_data/Linux/source/go/src/sync/once.go:44 +0xbe
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol.(*rawConnection).close(0xc4207300c0, 0x0, 0x0)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol/protocol.go:820 +0x6b
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol.(*rawConnection).readerLoop.func1(0xc4207300c0, 0xc420efbfd0)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol/protocol.go:335 +0x41
panic(0xa75380, 0x1117ca0)
    /media/ext4_data/Linux/source/go/src/runtime/panic.go:502 +0x229
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/db.(*FileSet).IndexID(0x0, 0xffffffffffffffff, 0xffffffffffffffff, 0xffffffffffffffff, 0xffffffffffffffff, 0xc422e5c501)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/db/set.go:263 +0x5e
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model.(*Model).ClusterConfig(0xc420211320, 0x4b91a04c26d701c3, 0xeb45ab20275c2e1e, 0x81bc97fd845af037, 0x4df64d3c0e0a8595, 0xc420ea8500, 0x4, 0x4)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model/model.go:949 +0xda6
github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol.(*rawConnection).readerLoop(0xc4207300c0, 0x0, 0x0)
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol/protocol.go:361 +0xed0
created by github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol.(*rawConnection).Start
    /media/ext4_data/Coding/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/protocol/protocol.go:225 +0x43

[snip]
```

I'll see if I can reproduce the original symlink related error above.
This is only occurring when interacting with folders from v.14.49-dirty.

Resuming the problematic device and folder:

```
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem windows root hack: /home/jamieson/XXX
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem tilde expansion: /home/jamieson/XXX
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem EvalSymlinks: /oldssd/jamieson/XXX
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem start: ~/Ph1
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem windows root hack: ~/Ph1
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem tilde expansion: /home/jamieson/Ph1
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: newBasicFilesystem EvalSymlinks failed: /home/jamieson/Ph1 lstat /oldssd/jamieson/Ph1: no such file or directory
[SGBHH] 10:28:35 INFO: Adding folder "XXX" (xxx)
panic: cannot start already running folder xxx
[monitor] 10:28:35 WARNING: Panic detected, writing to "zzz/panic-20180807-102835.log"
```

N.B., this running folder issue is a different folder than the original camera folder shared from device; disabling auto accept got that original folder working, and I haven't been able to reproduce that issue until this new one popped up.

The nil deref is completely unrelated to everything else - thanks anyway for finding it ;)

The cannot start already running folder almost certainly is #5063.

Does a folder for `/oldssd/jamieson/Ph1` actually exist? Because above in the gist and panic, it was `/home/jamieson/Essential-Ph1-Camera/`.

issue.title: lib/model, lib/protocol: Fix error handling when terminating a connection

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

In the protocol's readerloop do actually set the err variable instead of
returning directly, such that it is correctly passed to c.close in the deferred
statement.
In the model do a nil-check before calling err.Error().

### Testing

Simple unit test that doesn't panic anymore.
